IMAGE-THUMBNAIL APCATA 15016 S0926-860X(14)00586-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2014.09.035 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Time evolution of 4-chlorophenol conversion and selectivity to reaction products in the HDC of 4-CP with the Pd (a) and Rh (b) catalysts. Fig. 2 Reaction pathways for 4-CP HDC with the Pd (a) and Rh (b) catalysts. Fig. 3 HDC of 4-CP with the Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared at 200°C (a) and 400°C (b) calcination temperature. Experimental (symbols) and predicted (solid lines) values. Fig. 4 HDC of 4-CP with the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared at 200°C (a) and 400°C (b) calcination temperature. Experimental (symbols) and predicted (solid lines) values. Fig. 5 Deconvolution of the Pd 3d core-level spectra of Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared at 200°C (a) and 400°C (b) calcination temperature. Fig. 6 Deconvolution of the Rh 3d core-level spectra of Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared at 200°C (a) and 400°C (b) calcination temperature. Fig. 7 Deconvolution of the Fe 3p core-level spectra of Pd-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts reduced at 150°C (a), 250°C (b) and 350°C (c). The insets show photographs of the catalysts separated by a magnet. Table 1 Characterization of the own-prepared catalysts used in this work. Catalysts Preparation conditions Bulk metal content (wt%) S BET (m2 g−1) Calcination temperature (°C) Reduction temperature (°C) Pd Rh Fe Monometallic Pd/γ-Al2O3 200 350 1.1 – – 129 300 129 400 131 Rh/γ-Al2O3 200 350 – 1.0 – 128 300 130 400 131 Fe/γ-Al2O3 200 350 – – 4.1 135 300 135 400 150 136 250 137 350 136 Bimetallic Pd-Fe/γ-Al2O3 400 350 1.0 – 4.1 128 Rh-Fe/γ-Al2O3 400 350 – 0.9 4.0 129 Table 2 Values of the apparent rate constants (Lh−1 gcat −1) of equations 1–4. Casas Juan J. Rodriguez Ingenieria Quimica, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Crta. Colmenar km 15, 28049 Madrid, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +34 91 497 3991; fax: +34 91 497 3516. Graphical abstract The activity of monometallic (Pd or Rh) and bimetallic (iron-bearing) catalysts has been tested in the HDC of 4-chlorophenol (4-CP) in aqueous phase. The catalysts were prepared by a simple procedure consisting of incipient wetness impregnation followed by calcination and reduction at different temperatures. This allowed controlling the size, dispersion and oxidation state of the metallic nanoparticles. Increasing the temperature of calcination led to a higher dispersion of the active phase (from 21 to 46% by increasing the calcination temperature from 200 to 400°C) and a higher ratio of zerovalent to electrodefficient palladium (M0/M n+ values from 1.15 to 2.17) in the case of the Pd-catalysts. Those calcined in air at 400°C and reduced with H2 at 350°C yielded the highest values of the pseudo-first-order rate constant of 4-CP dechlorination (16.2Lh−1 gcat −1). The introduction of iron reduced the metal dispersion of both Pd and Rh but the catalysts maintained their dechlorination activity and showed magnetic properties useful for further separation from the liquid phase. Keywords Catalytic hydrodechlorination 4-Chlorophenol Pd and Rh catalysts Magnetic catalysts. 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrodechlorination (HDC) is a promising technology for the treatment of wastewater containing organic chlorinated pollutants. So far, it has been successfully applied to different types of chlorinated compounds such as chlorophenols (CPs), chlorobenzenes or polychlorobiphenyls [1–4]. The process is based on the reaction of the organochlorinated compound with hydrogen to produce hydrogen chloride and the corresponding chlorine-free byproduct. This transformation is commonly associated to a significant reduction of the ecotoxicity. Though there are a number of processes potentially available for the treatment of chlorinated organic pollutants like incineration, adsorption, biological treatment or advanced oxidation [5–8], HDC represents an environmentally friendly alternative with important advantages. In contrast to the aforementioned techniques, HDC can be operated under ambient-like (or close) temperature and pressure, shows a low sensitivity to pollutants concentration, is not affected by the toxicity of the chlorinated compounds and does not lead to more toxic by-products [9,10] as occur upon advanced oxidation [8,11–13]. However, HDC does not achieve the complete degradation of the organic pollutants and thus it is regarded mostly as a detoxifying pretreatment prior to biological or other oxidation treatments [2,14]. A number of catalysts based on noble and transition metals (Pd, Pt, Rh Cu and Ni) have been tested in aqueous-phase hydrodechlorination, being those based on palladium and rhodium the most active [1–3]. Regarding the support, carbon [10,15] and alumina [3,16] have attracted the main attention although some other, like pillared clays, have also been studied [17,18]. Activated carbon is an interesting catalyst support due to its high porosity and surface area, but alumina-supported catalysts have shown higher activity and stability so that they have been postulated as a better option by some authors. Yuan and Keane [19] investigated hydrodechlorination of chlorophenols over Pd/C and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, concluding that Pd/Al2O3 is less susceptible to deactivation, whereas Pd/C undergoes an appreciable loss of activity due to a marked decrease in the surface area and to Pd leaching. The high adsorption capacity of activated carbon can lead to a decrease in the catalyst surface area upon micro- and mesoporous blockage [20–22]. A number of authors have concluded that HDC is a structure-sensitive reaction [23–25]. Thus, the catalyst performance has shown to be affected by the size and electronic structure of the metal particles. In general, it is accepted that a higher surface-to-volume ratio, associated to a lower nanoparticle size of the active phase, increases the catalytic activity [23,25]. Other important factor influencing the catalytic activity is the oxidation state of the metal nanoparticles, which has been linked by some authors to the own particle size [25,26]. Therefore, the design of the catalysts with controlled nanoparticle size and oxidation state has gained large attention in the literature in the last few years [25,27,28]. However, the synthesis of nanoparticles usually involves complex and expensive procedures. Therefore, it is of interest the possibility of using simple conventional procedures capable of yielding catalysts with metallic nanoparticles of controlled size and oxidation state. In this sense, the calcination and reduction steps are two important milestones in the preparation of supported metallic catalysts and the temperature is a critical variable in both cases since it plays a significant role on the metal–support interaction, affecting the nature of the species as well as the dispersion of the active phase. Nevertheless, so far there are only few studies that analyze the effect of those issues on the properties of HDC catalysts and they have been mainly related to activated carbon-supported catalysts [29,30]. In addition to the fact that HDC is structure-sensitive and the catalysts have to be prepared paying special attention to the metal particle size and oxidation state, it is also important to consider the separation from the aqueous phase when used for the abatement of water pollutants. In this context, the preparation of bimetallic catalysts containing iron for the sake of developing magnetic properties without impairing their activity represents an interesting challenge. This attempt has been scarcely studied in the literature so far [31], being the main objectives of iron inclusion to reduce the cost of the final catalyst and improve its activity and stability [32–34]. The aim of this work is to prepare palladium and rhodium γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts with controlled size and dispersion of the active phase as well as the oxidation state of the nanoparticles by simply acting on the calcination and reduction temperature. The inclusion of iron with the purpose of developing magnetic properties in the catalyst allowing an easy separation is also studied. The activity and selectivity of the catalysts were tested in the hydrodechlorination of 4-chlorophenol (4-CP) in aqueous phase. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Preparation and characterization of the catalysts Monometallic (Pd/γ-Al2O3, Rh/γ-Al2O3, Fe/γ-Al2O3) and bimetallic (Pd-Fe/γ-Al2O3, Rh-Fe/γ-Al2O3) catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of powdered γ-Al2O3 supplied by Merck (Germany). The palladium, rhodium and iron precursors were aqueous solutions of PdCl2, RhCl3 and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, respectively. In the case of the bimetallic catalysts, a co-impregnation of both metals, palladium or rhodium and iron, in a single path was carried out. The Pd and Rh loads were adjusted to a nominal 1% (w/w), whereas the Fe load was fixed at 4% (w/w). After impregnation, all the solids were left for 2h at room temperature, dried for 12h at 60°C and finally calcined at different temperatures, within the range of 200–400°C in air atmosphere for 4h [31]. After calcination, the catalysts were reduced in H2 flow (50NmLmin−1) for 2h. Influence of reduction temperature within the range of 150–350°C was evaluated for the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [31], whereas the catalysts containing precious metals were reduced at 350°C. The porous structure of the fresh and used catalysts was characterized from nitrogen adsorption–desorption at −196°C using a Micromeritics Tristar 3020 apparatus. The samples were previously outgassed overnight at 150°C to a residual pressure of <10−3 Torr. Bulk rhodium, palladium and iron contents were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP/MS Elan 6000 Perkin-Elmer Sciex) after digestion of the samples with HNO3/HCl mixture. Elemental analyses of the fresh and used catalysts were carried out in a LECO CHNS-932 Elemental Analyzer. The chlorine content of the catalysts was determined by total reflection X-ray fluorescence (TXRF), using a TXRF spectrometer 8030c. Surface iron, palladium and rhodium species were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha apparatus equipped with a Kα X-ray excitation source, 1486.68eV. The software “XPS-Peak” was used for spectrograms deconvolution. The surface metal content was calculated from the area of the spectral peaks. Dispersion and metal particle size of the catalysts were determined from CO chemisorption at room temperature in a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2750 automated system equipped with Chemisoft TPx software. Stoichiometry of the CO adsorption over the Pd and Rh atoms was assumed to be 1:1 [35,36]. Table 1 summarizes the catalysts prepared as well as their measured bulk metal content and BET surface area. 2.2 Experimental procedure Hydrodechlorination of 4-CP was carried out in aqueous phase at starting concentrations of 200mgL−1. HDC runs were performed in a glass slurry-type reactor (500mL) where hydrogen was continuously fed at 50NmLmin−1. A catalyst concentration of 2gL−1 and 30°C temperature were always used. The existence of mass transfer limitations was discarded after some preliminary experiments where the effect of the catalyst particle size (50–200μm) and stirring velocity (400–900rpm) were checked. The initial rate values were independent of particle size below 150μm and of the stirring velocity within the range of 600–900rpm. Thus, to avoid internal and external mass transfer limitations, the catalyst was used in powdered form (dp <100μm) and the stirring velocity at 700rpm. Each run was carried out by triplicate being the standard deviation less than 5% in all cases. Preliminary blank experiments were conducted which confirmed the very low adsorption of 4-CP by all the catalysts prepared in this work (less than 5% reduction of the initial concentration). 2.3 Analytical methods The progress of the HDC process was followed by periodically withdrawing and analyzing liquid samples from the reactor. The catalyst was separated by filtration using a PTFE filter (pore size 0.45μm). 4-CP, phenol and cyclohexanone were analyzed by GC/FID (430-GC, Varian) using a 30m length and 0.25mm i.d. capillary column (CP-Wax 52 CB, Varian) and nitrogen as carrier gas. Chloride was quantified by ion chromatography (Metrohm 790 Personal IC). A Metrosep A supp 5-250 column (25cm length, 4mm internal diameter) was used as stationary phase and a 3.2mM Na2CO3 aqueous solution as the mobile phase. Total organic carbon (TOC) was measured using a TOC analyzer (Shimadzu, mod. TOC, VSCH). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic hydrodechlorination of 4-CP with Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts Fig. 1 shows the evolution of 4-CP conversion and the selectivity to reaction products upon reaction time in the HDC of 4-CP (100mgL−1 aqueous solution) with the monometallic Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared at 200 and 350°C calcination and reduction temperature, respectively. With the Pd catalyst, almost 90% dechlorination was achieved in 5min reaction time, whereas with the Rh catalyst only around 50% was reached at that time. However, both catalysts allowed complete dechlorination after 30min reaction time. The Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst gave rise to phenol (Ph) as the major reaction product. The selectivity toward phenol decreased with time as increasing amounts of cyclohexanone (C-one) were formed. These results are consistent with a consecutive reaction pathway where 4-CP reacts with hydrogen to produce phenol, which is further hydrogenated to cyclohexanone. In the case of the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, 4-CP was converted into phenol within the first minutes of reaction and it was rapidly hydrogenated to produce cyclohexanone, which was further hydrogenated to cyclohexanol (C-ol). At the end of the experiment (3h), the selectivity toward cyclohexanol was almost 100%. A high selectivity toward this compound is desirable from an environmental point of view since it is, by far, the less ecotoxic compound among the HDC by-products [3,37,38]. The carbon and chlorine balances, based on the identified species, were closed at 95 and 100%, respectively. Due to the HCl formation during HDC of 4-CP, the pH of the reaction medium decreased from the initial value (pH0 6) to ≈3.5. Based on these results, the reaction schemes of Fig. 2 are proposed. These schemes differ from the ones previously reported by Diaz et al. [3] with commercial Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalysts under the same operating conditions. They proposed a series–parallel pathway where 4-CP was converted into phenol and cyclohexanone but this last was also produced by phenol hydrogenation as well as cyclohexanol. However, and most important, in that study complete dechlorination of 4-CP was not achieved even after 3h reaction time and cyclohexanol was formed only in low amounts. Molina et al. [18] have recently reported results more similar to our current ones working with Pd and Rh supported on pillared clays. From the reaction schemes of Fig. 2, the following kinetic model is proposed, based on simple pseudo-first-order rate equations, where the H2 (high excess) and catalyst concentration (always 2gL−1) are included in the kinetic constants. (1) − d C 4 -CP d t = k H 1 ⋅ C 4 -CP (2) d C Ph d t = k H 1 ⋅ C 4 -CP − k H 2 ⋅ C Ph (3) d C C-one d t = k H 2 ⋅ C Ph − k H 3 ⋅ C C-one (4) d C C-ol d t = k H 3 ⋅ C C-one Table 2 reports the values of the apparent rate constants obtained by fitting the models to the experimental results using Scientist 3.0 software. In all cases, a frankly good fit of the experimental data to the proposed model was observed. Looking at the values of k H1, it can be concluded that the Pd catalyst shows a higher hydrodechlorination activity, in contrast with the results reported by Diaz et al. [3] with commercial Pd/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 catalysts where close similar activities were observed for both metals. Molina et al. [18] found that Rh was more active than Pd working with pillared clays-supported catalyst under similar conditions. Nevertheless, they explained that fact by the higher dispersion values of the Rh catalyst, whereas Pd yielded a higher specific activity. The values of k H2 in Table 2 reveal a significantly higher activity of the Rh/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the hydrogenation of phenol, giving rise to a much higher selectivity to cyclohexanone in the initial stages of the reaction. Finally, cyclohexanone was further hydrogenated to cyclohexanol with the Rh catalyst but that rate constant (k H3) was fairly lower than k H1 and k H2. 3.2 Influence of calcination temperature Figs. 3 and 4 show the evolution of 4-CP and the reaction products upon HDC with the Pd and Rh catalysts, respectively, prepared at two different calcination temperatures (200 and 400°C). As can be seen, increasing the calcination temperature increases the activity of the Pd catalyst for hydrodechlorination as well as for further hydrogenation of the phenol resulting from that first step. Nevertheless, in the case of Rh, no significant changes were observed. The values of the apparent rate constants collected in Table 3 for the Pd and Rh catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures confirm the above conclusions on the effect of that variable. In contrast to the significant influence of the calcination temperature on the catalyst selectivity of Pd/γ-Al2O3, the reduction temperature (varied in the range of 150–350°C) showed a negligible effect. Thus, we focused our attention on the characterization and performance of the catalysts obtained varying the calcination temperature. To explain the results obtained, the catalysts were characterized in terms of metal dispersion, mean metal particle size (both from CO chemisorption) and the ratio of zerovalent to electrodeficient metal species (M0/M n+) by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Table 4 summarizes the results obtained. The core-level spectra of Pd 3d and Rh 3d are given in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively. The deconvolution of those XPS profiles shows the existence of zerovalent and electrodeficient species in both catalysts. The zerovalent (Pd0) and electrodeficient (Pd n+) bands were centered at binding energy values of 335 and 337.5eV, respectively [34,39,40]. A number of authors [18,25,41] established that both zerovalent (Pd0) and electrodeficient (Pd n+) palladium species are required for hydrodechlorination of organochlorinated compounds. Increasing the calcination temperature from 200 to 400°C led to a significant increase in the Pd0/Pd n+ ratio from 1.15 to 2.17 (Table 4). Thus, the presence of higher proportion of Pd0 seems to improve the catalytic activity. A higher calcination temperature led also to a significant increase in the metal dispersion and a reduction of the mean size of Pd particles, as reported in Table 4. This fact seems to be also associated with the higher activity of the catalyst calcined at 400°C, which allowed a faster dechlorination and a higher selectivity towards the most hydrogenated reaction product, cyclohexanone. Baeza et al. [25] demonstrated that there is a relationship between the Pd0/Pd n+ ratio and the mean particle size, showing the smallest particles (2.7–4.2nm) the highest Pd0/Pd n+ ratios (2.86–1.49). They also reported that decreasing the particle size of Pd leads to an increase in catalytic activity in the aqueous-phase HDC of 4-CP. According to several studies [42–44], the activation of Pd/Al2O3 under an O2 atmosphere is due to reconstruction. Palladium particles reconstructed by breaking large particles into both PdO dispersed on Al2O3 and large Pd particles with PdO on the metal surface. In this sense, Zou and Gonzalez [45] also found that pre-treatment of a Pd/SiO2 catalyst in oxygen at temperatures in the range of 100–300°C led to higher dispersion of around 40%. Similarly, Cordi and Falconer [46] established that heat treatment under oxygen of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst at 500°C prior to the reduction step in H2 redispersed Pd on the surface. On the other hand, although decreasing Pd particle size increases the catalytic activity due to higher surface area, the larger particles obtained at low calcination temperatures show a more active surface looking at the intrinsic activity (expressed as turnover frequency, TOF) (Table 3). These results are in good agreement with those reported by Baeza et al. [25], who also obtained the highest activity values with the smallest nanoparticles but the largest ones exhibited higher activity per unit of metal surface. The higher catalytic activity showed by the largest nanoparticles can be related to a combination of different factors. According to Karpinski et al. [47], the higher activity of large particles compared to small ones can be ascribed to geometric factors since the hydrodechlorination reaction requires relatively large ensembles, the number of which increases with increasing particle size. Other authors claimed the importance of electronic factors and postulate that large electron-rich particles may assist in the cleavage of C-Cl bonds through electron transfer to the carbon atom, which will bear a partial positive charge owing to the electronegative character of the chlorine atom [48,49]. Alternatively, the differential solubility of hydrogen in large and small palladium particles could also play an important role since large palladium particles adsorb hydrogen to a greater extent than smaller ones [50,51]. Finally, the better resistance of larger Pd particles to inhibition/poisoning by chlorine should also be considered [25,52]. The deconvolution of the core-level spectra of Rh 3d also shows the presence of zerovalent (Rh0) and electrodeficient (Rh n+) rhodium species, centered at binding energy values of 307.7 and 308.9eV, respectively. However, the Rh0/Rh n+ ratio remained practically unchanged with the calcination temperature and the same can be said for the metal dispersion and mean particle size. These results are consistent with the observed non-significant effect of calcination temperature on the activity of the Rh catalyst. 3.3 Magnetic catalysts The development of magnetic properties on the catalysts can be of interest for the sake of an easier separation from the liquid phase. Thus, we have checked that possibility upon the introduction of iron. In a first approach, a monometallic Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared at a calcination temperature of 400°C was tested in the HDC of 4-CP. This catalyst did not show any significant dechlorination activity. Golubina et al. [32] and Choi et al. [53] arrived to the same conclusion with other iron-based catalysts. Thus, the introduction of iron on the Pd and Rh catalysts tested so far is not expected to improve their activity but only developing magnetic properties useful for further separation from the reaction medium. In that sense, the reduction step must be critical and, then, different temperatures within 150–350°C have been tested for that step of the preparation of bimetallic Pd–Fe and Rh–Fe catalysts. The development of magnetic properties was observed in the catalysts prepared at the highest reduction temperature (350°C). Calcination was accomplished always at 400°C. Fig. 7 shows the Fe 3p core-level XPS spectra of the bimetallic Pd–Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared at three different reduction temperatures. The bands corresponding to Fe(III) and Fe(II) are centered at binding energy values around 55.6 and 53.8eV, respectively [54]. In the catalyst reduced at 150°C, only the presence of Fe(III) was detected while increasing the reduction temperature led to higher amounts of Fe(II) in the catalyst. In fact, the Fe(II):Fe(III) ratio calculated for the catalyst reduced at 350°C was 0.45, similar to the theoretical stoichiometric ratio of magnetite [54]. The results obtained in the hydrodechlorination of 4-CP with the catalysts with and without Fe reduced at 350°C and calcined at 400°C are summarized in Table 5 . As can be seen, the addition of iron in both the Pd- and Rh increased the dechlorination rate (k H1 value) but decreased the rates of further hydrogenation (k H2 and k H3), especially in the case of the Pd catalyst, where a significant decrease in the selectivity to cyclohexanone was observed. Thus, in spite of the fact that the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst did not show any significant dechlorination activity, a synergistic effect seems to occur upon the introduction of Fe on the Pd and Rh catalysts. This increase in hydrodechlorination activity can be related to the combination of Fe and Pd or Rh, since the Pd–Fe interface has been reported to enhance hydrogen spill over [34]. Data on the characterization of the catalysts by XPS and CO chemisorption are included in Table 6 . The addition of Fe led apparently to a lower dispersion of the active phase in both the Pd and Rh catalysts. However, the metal dispersion has been evaluated from CO chemisorption and the decreased CO uptake associated to the introduction of iron can be due to surface encapsulation of Pd and Rh by large Fe aggregates, thus reducing the availability of Pd and Rh sites. That could explain the lower hydrogenation activity of the Fe-bearing catalysts, in agreement with previous results in the literature [34,55]. The decreased CO uptake of the Fe-bearing catalysts may be due also to the formation of Pd–Fe and Rh–Fe alloys [56]. Witonska et al. [57] also found a significant decrease on CO chemisorption when iron was incorporated onto monometallic Pd/Al2O3 catalysts. The dispersion decreased from 23 to 3% in 5% Pd/Al2O3 and 5% Pd-20%Fe/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. Accordingly, they observed a decrease in the hydrogenation activity from phenol to cyclohexanone although they also found a higher dechlorination activity. This fact was explained by the overlapping effects of active phase dispersion, surface structure and chemical composition. On the other hand, the ratio of zerovalent to electrodeficient metallic species increased somewhat in the Pd catalyst upon the introduction of iron and that may partially explain its higher hydrodechlorination activity. Nevertheless, the opposite was observed in the Rh catalyst. The values of the M0/M n+ ratio, obtained from the XPS spectra, can be affected by the above-mentioned encapsulation of Pd and Rh by Fe aggregates and the formation of Pd–Fe and Rh–Fe alloys, thus reducing the conclusive value of those data. Elemental analyses confirmed that the deposition of carbon-containing species on the surface of the catalysts was almost negligible (<0.5%). The presence of chlorine over the catalysts was also discarded by TXRF analyses. The values of the BET surface area as well as those of the bulk metal content are summarized in Table 7 . As observed, the BET surface area of the catalysts remained unchanged after use (see Table 1). Regarding the metal content of the catalysts, it has to be pointed out that there was no significant palladium or rhodium loss during the 3h-HDC experiments, whereas iron leaching reached around 10% in all cases (see values of Table 1). In this sense, further research is needed to improve the anchorage of Fe on the catalysts surface trying to reduce Fe leaching. Golubina et al. [32] showed that during HDC iron oxides react with HCl giving rise to FeCl3, whose formation is thermodynamically favored respect to PdCl2. In this sense, they concluded that the stability of bimetallic Pd–Fe catalysts is higher than that of the monometallic Pd ones since the poisoning effect of HCl on Pd active sites would be substantially reduced upon removal of chlorine as FeCl3. They also explained the better performance of the bimetallic Pd–Fe catalysts by the stabilization of small metal particles as well as the formation of alloys, which could change the geometry of the active sites and thus modify the activity of the catalyst. Finally, it has to be considered as well that HCl can also interact with the γ-Al2O3 support, thus preventing the poisoning of Pd active sites [58]. These authors showed that during HDC iron oxides react with HCl giving rise to FeCl3, whose formation is thermodynamically favored with respect to PdCl2. In this sense, they concluded that the stability of bimetallic Pd–Fe catalysts is higher than that of the monometallic Pd ones since the poisoning effect of HCl on Pd active sites would be substantially reduced by elimination of chlorine as FeCl3. They also supported the better performance of bimetallic Pd–Fe catalysts with regard to the Pd monometallic ones by the stabilization of small metal particles as well as the formation of alloys, which could change the geometry of the active sites and thus modify the activity of the catalyst. With regard to the magnetic properties of the Fe-bearing catalysts, it has to be highlighted that those reduced at 350°C were easily separated from the reaction medium by applying an external magnetic field. 4 Conclusions The temperature of calcination showed a significant effect on the activity of own-prepared Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the HDC of 4-CP. Increasing that temperature within the 200–400°C range showed to increase the dechlorination activity as well as that of further hydrogenation of the resulting phenol. This can be explained by the increase in the metallic dispersion (with reduction of the mean metal particle size) and the M0/M n+ ratio. However, the larger particles formed at the lowest calcination temperature showed a more active surface looking at the activity per unit surface area. On the opposite, the calcination temperature did not affect to the activity of the Rh catalysts. These lasts showed a lower dechlorination activity but were more active for further hydrogenation, leading to cyclohexanol as the final reaction product with almost 100% selectivity after 3h. Both the Pd and Rh catalysts allowed complete dechlorination of 4-CP in short reaction time (<15min) under ambient-like conditions. The introduction of iron on the Pd and Rh catalysts allows development of strong magnetic properties upon reduction at 350°C without impairing their activity, which was even improved for the dechlorination step. These magnetic properties are useful for easier separation of the catalyst from the liquid phase after use. It has to be also highlighted that the catalysts showed a high stability with negligible Pd leaching. The γ-Al2O3 support as well as Fe can react with HCl, preventing the poisoning of Pd. coredata.dc:description: The activity of monometallic (Pd or Rh) and bimetallic (iron-bearing) catalysts has been tested in the HDC of 4-chlorophenol (4-CP) in aqueous phase. The catalysts were prepared by a simple procedure consisting of incipient wetness impregnation followed by calcination and reduction at different temperatures. This allowed controlling the size, dispersion and oxidation state of the metallic nanoparticles. Increasing the temperature of calcination led to a higher dispersion of the active phase (from 21 to 46% by increasing the calcination temperature from 200 to 400°C) and a higher ratio of zerovalent to electrodefficient palladium (M0/M n+ values from 1.15 to 2.17) in the case of the Pd-catalysts. Those calcined in air at 400°C and reduced with H2 at 350°C yielded the highest values of the pseudo-first-order rate constant of 4-CP dechlorination (16.2Lh−1 gcat −1). The introduction of iron reduced the metal dispersion of both Pd and Rh but the catalysts maintained their dechlorination activity and showed magnetic properties useful for further separation from the liquid phase.
coredata.dc:title: Improved γ-alumina-supported Pd and Rh catalysts for hydrodechlorination of chlorophenols
